H0.text: Capillary tube is the phenomenon related to the relative strength of cohesive and adhesive forces, described as the tendency of a fluid to be raised or suppressed in a narrow tube.

H1.text: Melting tube is the phenomenon related to the relative strength of cohesive and adhesive forces, defined as the tendency of a fluid to be raised or suppressed in a narrow tube, also known as capillary action.

H2.text: Cohesive tube is the phenomenon of capillary action—the tendency of a fluid to be raised or suppressed in a narrow tube due to the relative strength of cohesive and adhesive forces.

H3.text: Pressure tube is the name given to capillary action, which is the tendency of a fluid to be raised or suppressed in a narrow tube due to the relative strength of cohesive and adhesive forces.

A4.text: a common apparatus used to demonstrate the phenomenon is the capillary tube

A5.text: the height h of a liquid column is given by Jurin's law h=2γcosθ/(ρgr), where r is the radius of the tube
